data.title: Were Pechenegs, Cumans, and Tatars considered Asian?
data.meta_description: Excluding the Mongols, is it accurate to call the historical empires of the Eurasian steppe, such as Cumans, Pechenegs, Huns, Tatars, and Kipchaks "Asian"...
data.text:
Joined May 2016

74 Posts | 3+

US

Discussion Starter

Jun 20, 2018

Last edited: Jun 20, 2018

#1

Last edited: Jun 20, 2018

Excluding the Mongols, is it accurate to call the historical empires of the Eurasian steppe, such as Cumans, Pechenegs, Huns, Tatars, and Kipchaks "Asian" (possibly anachronistic for the time period)?

If so, why? If not, why not?

Joined May 2009

1,684 Posts | 276+

Jun 20, 2018

#2

They're usually called Turkic or Turco-Mongolian, or just steppe nomads. People of the period would refer to them by whatever generic name was most popular for steppe nomads. A lot of westerners for example still called steppe horsemen Scythians even in the middle ages.

If we're talking about racial identification, steppe hordes were often multi-ethnic, so blanket racial labels usually didn't apply. Some Cumans had east Asian features, others looked white. Same with the Huns and later various Turkic groups.

Joined Jun 2014

2,589 Posts | 89+

Venice

Jun 20, 2018

#3

The majority of the Steppe peopulations were Indoeuropean and so european looking, only the mongols in the far east were asiatic, then after the mongol spread out the proportions changed and intermixed with some confederations happening.
